Application_Facts: Cannon sought to summon a prosecuting officer as a witness, alleging conspiracy; the board quashed the summons, finding insufficient evidence.
Procedural_Issue: Quashing of a summons to a witness in an R.C.M.P. disciplinary hearing
Jurisdictional_Issue: Board's discretion over procedural matters under the Royal Canadian Mounted Police Act
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence to support the need for the summoned witness
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of the board's decision
Remedy_Sought: Restoration of the summons or intervention based on alleged Charter violations
Decision_Rationale: The decision was interlocutory and within the board's procedural authority; section 11(d) does not apply as the proceeding is not penal

Application_Facts: Cannon attempted to summon Sgt. Keating as a witness in disciplinary proceedings related to sexual harassment allegations; the board quashed the summons.
Procedural_Issue: Quashing of a summons to a witness in an interlocutory decision
Jurisdictional_Issue: Scope of judicial review over interlocutory decisions in internal disciplinary processes
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of sufficient justification for the necessity of the witness
Relief_Sought: Judicial review based on alleged violations of procedural fairness and Charter rights
Remedy_Sought: Intervention by the court to compel witness testimony
Decision_Rationale: Disciplinary process is administrative and internal, not penal; no special circumstances warranting intervention; no violation of procedural fairness or Charter rights

Crimes.Crime_Name: Disobeying a lawful order under the Royal Canadian Mounted Police Act Regulations
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the R.C.M.P. Tribunal violates s. 11(d) of the Canadian Charter and s. 23 of the Quebec Charter due to lack of impartiality
Crimes.Governing_Law: Royal Canadian Mounted Police Act Regulations, Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms s. 11(d), Quebec Charter s. 23
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Officer refused to cooperate with investigation without legal counsel
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Not applicable – issue focused on legal interpretation
Crimes.Legal_Rule: s. 11(d) applies to criminal or quasi-criminal proceedings, not internal disciplinary matters; Quebec Charter does not apply to federal bodies
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Lack of impartiality and independence of tribunal
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Nature of penalties and purpose of tribunal
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Internal disciplinary process under federal jurisdiction
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Royal Canadian Mounted Police Act Regulations

Crimes.Crime_Name: Conduct unbecoming an officer under the Royal Canadian Mounted Police Act
Crimes.Governing_Law: Royal Canadian Mounted Police Act, Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms s. 11(d), Quebec Charter s. 23
Crimes.Application_Facts: R.C.M.P. officer refused to cooperate with investigation without legal counsel
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Applicability of provincial charter to federal body
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Record of refusal to cooperate during investigation
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not central – matter based on legal characterization
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Distinction between criminal and internal disciplinary proceedings
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Proceedings are disciplinary, not penal; charters do not apply

Crimes.Crime_Name: Behaving in a threatening manner towards another person under Penitentiary Service Regulations s. 39(g)
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Use of explicit threat to remain in protective custody
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: Threat not directly aimed at specific officer present
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Statement recorded and reviewed

Crimes.Crime_Name: Threatening to assault another person under Penitentiary Service Regulations s. 39(b)
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Generalized threat to harm next officer seen
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: Motivated by desire to avoid general population
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Statement documented and consistent
Crimes.Sentencing_Issue: Correct legal provision application pending review

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Federal Court has jurisdiction to review an immigration officer's refusal to amend a refugee claimant's name on official documents
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Singh initially provided a false name upon entry, later sought correction
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Request to correct name on official documents
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Decision not final or having legal consequences
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Finality and legal consequences of decision
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Decision must be final and have legal consequences for judicial review
Crimes.Application_Factor: Amending documents is a preliminary step
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Refusal to amend name upheld due to lack of jurisdiction
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Misrepresentation of identity in border documents

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Federal Court has jurisdiction to review an immigration officer's refusal to amend a refugee claimant's name on official documents
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Singh used a false name upon arrival, later requested correction
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Desire to correct false name on immigration records
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Name amendment is not a final decision with legal consequences
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Finality and legal impact of administrative decision
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Requirement of finality under s. 18.1 for judicial review
Crimes.Application_Factor: Correction request pertains to preliminary documentation
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Court declined jurisdiction; refusal not subject to review
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Use of false identity in immigration process

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section related to valid visa duration under immigration law
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants remained in the country beyond the authorized period of stay and were subject to a removal order
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review rendered academic due to stay order
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal court jurisdiction over immigration matters
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Visa records, removal order documentation, court stay order
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Deferral of removal and judicial review
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Stay of removal and reconsideration of deferral request
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness or correctness, depending on issue type
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Stay order halted removal, making the original judicial review application academic

Crimes.Violation_Type: Failure to comply with removal order
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Enforcement provisions under IRPA regarding removal orders
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants challenged the denial of deferral of removal after a stay was granted by the court
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review rendered academic due to stay order
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal court jurisdiction over immigration enforcement decisions
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Removal order, deferral request, judicial stay order
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Judicial review of enforcement decision and deferral of removal
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Stay of removal and reversal of deferral denial
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Stay of removal eliminated live controversy, rendering the matter moot
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Canada Border Services Agency, Federal Court

Crime_Name: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act Violation
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed forced marriage and abuse as basis for refugee status
Procedural_Issue: RAD's review of RPD's credibility findings
Judicial review of RAD's decision
Evidence_Used: Credibility assessment based on inconsistencies in applicant's testimony
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Inconsistencies in applicant's account affecting credibility
Credibility_Assessment: RPD doubted credibility due to inconsistencies; RAD upheld RPD's findings
Decision_Outcome: RPD rejected claim, RAD upheld rejection
Remedy_Sought: Certification of general importance questions (not granted)
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard applied to RAD's decision
Decision_Rationale: RAD properly deferred to RPD's credibility findings as they were based on reasonable grounds

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Visa refusal based on credibility and admissibility
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Can section 11 of the Act be a basis for visa refusal without specific inadmissibility findings?
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, sections 11(1) and 40(1)
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's inconsistent statements and discrepancies with family testimonies undermined credibility
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Inconsistent oral statements, conflicting family testimonies
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Doubt about non-inadmissibility due to misrepresentation
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to provide consistent and credible information
Crimes.Application_Factor: Credibility and consistency of applicant’s statements

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to answer truthfully as per section 16(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Violation_Type: Untruthful and evasive responses during interview
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, sections 16(1) and 11(1)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Inconsistent and vague responses regarding work history, family displacement, and LTTE involvement
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal court jurisdiction over judicial review
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of credible and consistent testimony
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer found applicant not credible due to inconsistencies and evasiveness
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Requirement to answer truthfully under section 16(1)
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Applicant failed to meet burden of proving non-inadmissibility due to lack of credibility

Legal_Provision_Violated: Subsection 72(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Applicants submitted new evidence regarding risks under China's one-child policy, including a U.S. Department of State report contradicting the RIR.
Procedural_Issue: PRRA officer failed to adequately address contradictory evidence, undermining transparency and justification.
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to explain contradiction between U.S. Department of State report and RIR
Outcome: Judicial review granted; decision set aside
Remedy_Sought: Matter referred for redetermination by a different officer
Decision_Rationale: Officer's decision was unreasonable due to failure to account for and explain conflicting evidence on country conditions

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Violation of procedural fairness by failing to disclose RCMP report and denying applicants a chance to respond
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Minister relied on RCMP investigation report instead of appointed investigator's report
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Ministerial Declaration and Order in Council set aside
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicants to demonstrate unfairness, met due to lack of disclosure
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: RCMP report used without verification or opportunity for rebuttal
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Procedural fairness required under Indian Act and Regulations
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Lack of disclosure and opportunity to respond
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Indian Act, election appeals, Ministerial discretion
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Not provided – applicants were not informed or given chance to respond
Crimes.Outcome: Decision set aside, matter returned for proper procedures
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Sections of the Indian Act and associated Regulations governing election disputes
Crimes.Authority: Minister of Indigenous and Northern Affairs Canada (INAC)

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Violation of procedural fairness by failing to disclose RCMP report and denying applicants an opportunity to respond
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Minister relied on RCMP report without sharing with applicants
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Ministerial Declaration and Order in Council invalidated
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicants to show procedural unfairness, successfully demonstrated
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Use of undisclosed RCMP findings affecting rights and reputations
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Procedural fairness required in administrative decisions under Indian Act
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Non-disclosure of evidence and denial of right to respond
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Administrative law principles, Indian Act provisions on elections
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Applicants denied opportunity to address allegations
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Judicial review and setting aside of Minister’s decision
Crimes.Outcome: Decision set aside, remanded to Minister for reconsideration with fair process
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Relevant sections of Indian Act regarding electoral disputes and Ministerial authority
Crimes.Authority: Minister of Indigenous and Northern Affairs Canada

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Violation of procedural fairness due to non-disclosure of RCMP report and lack of response opportunity
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Reliance on RCMP report over appointed investigator; no access given to applicants
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Ministerial Declaration and Order in Council invalidated
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: Applicants showed breach of natural justice
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Critical reliance on confidential RCMP findings without transparency
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Duty of fairness includes disclosure and right to be heard
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Failure to disclose investigative findings and deny response
Crimes.Defendant_Response: No opportunity provided for applicants to refute allegations
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Quashing of Minister’s declaration and order
Crimes.Outcome: Decisions set aside, matter referred back for proper procedure
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Provisions of Indian Act concerning band council elections and appeals

Crimes.Violation_Type: Alleged vote-buying during Band Council election
Crimes.Governing_Law: Indian Act and associated electoral rules
Crimes.Application_Facts: Election appeal led to RCMP investigation and Ministerial action based on undisclosed report
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Individuals affected by declaration of office vacancies
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Minister failed to disclose report or allow response
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Minister’s authority under Indian Act vs. procedural fairness obligations
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of disclosure and inability to challenge evidence
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: RCMP report accepted without applicant input or verification
Crimes.Outcome: Case remanded for reconsideration with adherence to procedural fairness
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Judicial review of Ministerial Declaration and Order in Council
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Setting aside of decisions and return to Minister for proper process
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Use of evidence without disclosure violates natural justice
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Minister of Indigenous and Northern Affairs Canada

Application_Facts: Mr. Sadek and Ms. Barakhe were absent from Canada for work but maintained Canadian homes, tax obligations, and family ties
Residency_Compliance: 1095 days physical residency required; absences deemed temporary with maintained ties
Procedural_Issue: Minister challenged Citizenship Judge's interpretation of residency requirements
Evidence_Used: Canadian homes, tax filings, family ties, employment-related absence details
Credibility_Assessment: Absences found to be temporary and reasonable by Citizenship Judge
Outcome: Mr. Sadek and Ms. Barakhe granted citizenship
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of Citizenship Judge's decision
Remedy_Sought: Overturning of citizenship grant based on residency grounds
Decision_Rationale: The Citizenship Judge correctly applied the 'roots' test and concluded absences were temporary with strong ties maintained to Canada

Application_Facts: Applicant provided various identity documents post-hearing but failed to submit them timely.
RPD found documents lacked probative value and were not new evidence.
Misrepresentation_Element: Inconsistent documentation and late submission of evidence undermined credibility.
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review analyzed procedural fairness, credibility assessment, and 'no credible basis' finding.
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to provide timely and credible identity documentation
Credibility_Assessment: RPD found no credible basis for the claim due to inconsistent and untimely documents.
Decision_Outcome: RPD did not err in rejecting documents.
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; no credible basis confirmed.
Decision_Rationale: Applicant failed to establish identity and provide credible evidence.

Legal_Issue: Whether RPD erred in rejecting applicant's identity documents and finding no credible basis.
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; no credible basis upheld.
Credibility_Assessment: RPD questioned authenticity due to discrepancies in dates of birth and names.
Evidence_Ignored: Post-hearing documents considered irrelevant due to pre-existence
Application_Factor: Timeliness and authenticity of submitted documents
Decision_Outcome: RPD decision upheld as within reasonable range
Document_Fraud: Discrepancies in names and dates of birth across documents

Dispute_Type: Credibility and procedural fairness in refugee claim
Legal_Issue: Whether RPD breached procedural fairness or erred in credibility assessment and 'no credible basis' finding.
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; no credible basis upheld.
Credibility_Assessment: Inconsistencies in dates of birth, names, and lack of timely documentation.
Evidence_Type: Multiple identity documents with conflicting information
Basis_of_Claim: Refugee protection based on nationality and risk
Application_Error: Failure to produce timely and credible documentation
Decision_Outcome: No breach of procedural fairness; credibility findings upheld.
Document_Fraud: Inconsistent identity documents indicating potential misrepresentation

Risk_Assessment: High risk due to lack of credible rehabilitation
Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient evidence of non-compliance and reoffending

Prior_Criminality: Repeated criminal behavior despite previous leniency
Risk_Assessment: High risk due to pattern of criminal conduct

Crime_Name: Failure to comply with a court order
Application_Facts: Applicant failed to meet conditions during stay period
Procedural_Issue: Request for postponement denied
Credibility_Assessment: Lack of diligence in seeking assessment
Remedy_Sought: Stay of removal based on humanitarian grounds
Decision_Rationale: No procedural fairness breach; applicant not diligent

Credibility_Assessment: Applicant lacked diligence in obtaining assessment
Legal_Provision: Rule 48 of the Immigration Appeal Division Rules

Legal_Issue: Refusal to postpone hearing and factual conclusions
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to show humanitarian grounds
Legal_Provision: Section related to humanitarian and compassionate grounds

Key_Evidence_Considered: Pattern of fraud, failure to comply with stay conditions
Defendant_Response: Sought delay to submit psycho-social assessment
Legal_Provision: Sections relating to H&C considerations and appeals

Application_Facts: Respondent was absent for 630 days, falling short of the 1095-day physical presence requirement in the four years preceding the application
Procedural_Issue: Citizenship Judge's reasons were inadequate and failed to address key evidence gaps
Evidence_Used: Family presence in Canada, property ownership, community involvement
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of documentation on physical presence and financial ties to Canada
Relief_Sought: Review of approval of citizenship application
Remedy_Sought: Overturning of the Citizenship Judge's decision
Decision_Rationale: Respondent did not meet the 1095-day physical presence requirement under any of the three legal tests; insufficient evidence and inadequate reasoning by the Citizenship Judge

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPR Section 181 - Failure to comply with conditions of stay
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants remained in Canada beyond the validity of their visas and applied for permanent residence on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant – failed to maintain legal status
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Alleged failure to adequately consider best interests of children
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over immigration decisions
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of financial documentation and police reports related to threats
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not challenged directly; focus on completeness of submission
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Permanent residence based on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Order for new assessment or reversal of decision
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No disproportionate hardship established; best interests of children considered but outweighed by immigration compliance

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Alleged omission of material evidence affecting H&C claim
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Failure to submit updated evidence of criminal threats and financial status
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), sections related to H&C considerations
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Consultant’s failure to submit documents did not establish applicant dishonesty
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 25(1) IRPA – Humanitarian and Compassionate considerations
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: New evidence not considered due to consultant error
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: No reasonable probability of different outcome
Crimes.Application_Error: Consultant failed to include critical documents
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None – officer was aware threats had ceased
Crimes.Application_Factor: Best interests of children, cessation of threats, business success

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Professional misconduct leading to failed immigration application
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Impact of consultant’s failure to submit evidence on application outcome
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Regulated Canadian Immigration Consultant standards
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Missing financial records and police reports on threats
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicants to prove incompetence and likely different result
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: No direct allegation of fraud, but professional oversight occurred
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Advisor incompetence must be proven with clear evidence affecting outcome
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Claim dismissed – no proof of impact
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Administrative law principles applied to immigration decisions
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Officer acted reasonably based on available information
Crimes.Authority: College of Immigration and Citizenship Consultants (CIIC), Immigration Officers

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Can the applicant access personal information about complainants under the Privacy Act?
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Applicant sought identities of those who complained to RCMP, alleging false information
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: RCMP's discretion aligned with the purpose of the Privacy Act
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Judicial review under s.41 of the Privacy Act
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Correctness for categorization, reasonableness for discretion

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Can the RCMP lawfully withhold personal information under Privacy Act exemptions?
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Applicant sought disclosure of complainants' identities to pursue civil remedies, alleging malicious false reporting
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: RCMP's discretion was reasonably exercised under the Privacy Act
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Judicial review under s.41 of the Privacy Act
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Correctness for categorization, reasonableness for discretion

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Can the RCMP withhold personal information under Privacy Act exemptions?
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Judicial review under s.41 of the Privacy Act
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Privacy Act exemptions apply to investigative records, third-party privacy, and solicitor-client privilege
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Correctness for categorization, reasonableness for discretion
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alex Barta sought personal information from RCMP records to identify individuals he believed gave false statements about him
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: No breach of Privacy Act found
Crimes.Defendant_Response: RCMP withheld information citing statutory exemptions

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant sought information about complainants to pursue civil action, claiming malicious false reporting
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Alleged false statements provided to RCMP
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Appeal after Privacy Commissioner upheld RCMP exemptions
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Disclosure of personal information of complainants
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Access to information under Privacy Act
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Exemptions under Privacy Act are justified if they protect investigations, third-party privacy, or legal privilege
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Correctness for categorization, reasonableness for discretion
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: RCMP's decision to withhold information was lawful and within statutory authority

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to meet work experience requirements for work permit
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations, s. 200(3)(a)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant had no prior cooking experience but possessed relevant certifications; LMO required three years of food service experience
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Assessment based on documentary evidence without interview
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over immigration decisions
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of verifiable work experience in cooking
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not challenged; qualifications accepted but insufficient
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Judicial review of visa officer's decision
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Overturn refusal and issue work permit
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Officer reasonably concluded applicant could not perform required work due to lack of experience
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Visa Officer, Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada

Crimes.Crime_Name: Work Permit Refusal under Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the visa officer reasonably refused the application due to lack of experience
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations, s. 200(3)(a)
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant’s qualifications credible but experience lacking
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Insufficient work experience despite other qualifications
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Three years of required cooking experience not met
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to meet explicit job requirement stated in LMO
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonable apprehension of inability to perform work
Crimes.Application_Factor: Experience requirement was mandatory per employer’s LMO

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with immigration requirements
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the immigration officer erred in denying the H&C claim
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Section 25
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Insufficient evidence of unusual or disproportionate hardship
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On the applicant to demonstrate humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Applicant had unauthorized stay and prior rejections
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Section 25 allows discretion to grant permanent residency on H&C grounds
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Claim denied due to lack of exceptional hardship
Key_Evidence_Considered: History of visa extensions and unauthorized stay
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Permanent residency based on H&C grounds

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants remained in Canada after visa expiry, refugee claims rejected
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Korean national with rejected refugee claim
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant – overstayed visa and unauthorized presence
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Not applicable – no finding of misrepresentation
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction under Section 72 of IRPA
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of proof of unusual or disproportionate hardship
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: History of non-compliance considered but not determinative
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Permanent residency on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No unusual or disproportionate hardship established

Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 5(1) of the Canadian Citizenship Act - physical presence requirement
Application_Facts: Applicant provided conflicting information about absences and insufficient evidence of physical presence in Canada
Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant - failed to demonstrate 1095 days of physical presence
Misrepresentation_Element: Potential misrepresentation due to inconsistent claims about absences
Procedural_Issue: Reliance on self-reported data without corroborating evidence
Evidence_Used: Applicant's submitted documents, absence records, residency timeline
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient proof of physical presence in Canada, conflicting absence data
Credibility_Assessment: Citizenship Judge found applicant's claims about presence not credible
Legal_Standard_Applied: Residency requirement under the Citizenship Act
Decision_Rationale: Judge reasonably concluded applicant did not meet burden of proving physical presence; discrepancies undermined credibility

Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s.96
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed FARC threats due to refusal of vacuna tax
Procedural_Issue: PRRA officer dismissed evidence as self-serving and uncorroborated
Federal Court reviewed under reasonableness standard
Evidence_Used: New evidence cited in judicial review
Credibility_Assessment: Officer found applicant's evidence lacked credibility
Legal_Standard_Applied: Assessment of subjective and objective risks of persecution
Decision_Rationale: No reviewable error; decision was reasonable and defensible

Crime_Name: Jeopardy Order under Income Tax Act
Legal_Provision_Violated: Subsection 225.2(2) of the Income Tax Act
Application_Facts: Mrs. Reddy was assessed $461,285.86 in taxes due to transfers from her son's account. The Minister applied for a Jeopardy Order ex parte, asserting that delay in collection would jeopardize recovery. Mr. Fowles' affidavit indicated potential asset transfer or liquidation. Mrs. Reddy challenged the order, citing insufficient disclosure and misrepresentation of her financial situation, but failed to raise reasonable doubt.
Misrepresentation_Element: Mrs. Reddy alleged misrepresentation of her financial situation in the application for the Jeopardy Order.
Procedural_Issue: Ex parte application by the Minister; Mrs. Reddy sought review under subsection 225.2(8) to set aside the order.
Evidence_Used: Affidavit of Mr. Fowles showing risk of asset transfer or liquidation.
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Mrs. Reddy argued insufficient disclosure, but no evidentiary deficiency was found by the court.
Credibility_Assessment: The court found Mr. Fowles' affidavit credible; Mrs. Reddy failed to cast reasonable doubt on the evidence presented.
Decision_Outcome: The application to set aside the Jeopardy Order was dismissed with costs.
Relief_Sought: Mrs. Reddy sought to set aside the Jeopardy Order.
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonable grounds to believe that delay in collection would jeopardize the assessed tax debt under subsection 225.2(2).
Decision_Rationale: The Minister met the threshold under subsection 225.2(2) based on credible evidence of jeopardy to collection; Mrs. Reddy did not rebut this with sufficient doubt.
Authority_Responsible: Judge authorized the Jeopardy Order upon application by the Minister.

Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), sections related to refugee appeal procedures
Governing_Law: Principles of administrative law regarding standard of review
Application_Facts: Meilina claimed refugee status but was denied by RPD based on internal flight alternative; RAD upheld decision using reasonableness standard; Federal Court found appeal process flawed
Procedural_Issue: Failure to provide proper appellate review
Lack of adequate reasoning in upholding RPD decision
Jurisdictional_Issue: Scope of RAD's duty to defer to RPD findings
Evidence_Used: RPD findings on internal flight alternative
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient justification for deferring to RPD on mixed fact and law issues
Credibility_Assessment: Assessed by RPD; not independently re-evaluated adequately by RAD
Standard_of_Review: Correctness standard implied by Federal Court for legal questions
Decision_Rationale: RAD must conduct meaningful review of RPD decisions involving mixed fact and law; mere deference insufficient when legal or procedural errors are present

Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, subsection 72(1)
Application_Facts: Applicant provided a University of Toronto evaluation confirming secondary education equivalence; visa officer did not analyze this evidence or allow applicant to respond to concerns.
Procedural_Issue: Failure to afford procedural fairness; no opportunity given to address discrepancies in educational credentials
Evidence_Used: Evaluation report from the University of Toronto
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Visa officer did not properly assess submitted educational evaluation
Credibility_Assessment: Doubts raised about educational credentials without verification or applicant input
Decision_Outcome: Visa application denied initially based on unverified doubts
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of application by a different visa officer
Decision_Rationale: Breach of procedural fairness occurred as applicant was not given chance to address concerns or have evidence properly assessed
Authority_Responsible: Visa officer at time of initial decision

Violation_Type: Failure to meet refugee eligibility criteria
Legal_Provision_Violated: Refugee Convention grounds: religion, nationality, political opinion, membership in a particular social group
Governing_Law: Refugee law - definition of persecution and well-founded fear
Application_Facts: Applicants faced discrimination in Israel including harassment and objections to military service
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of Refugee Division's decision
Evidence_Used: Reports of discrimination, personal claims of threats
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of evidence showing state inability to protect or systemic persecution
Credibility_Assessment: Claims deemed insufficient to establish a well-founded fear of persecution
Remedy_Sought: Judicial reversal of Refugee Division’s decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution under the Refugee Convention
Decision_Rationale: Discrimination alone does not amount to persecution; applicants failed to prove state protection failure or sustained human rights violations
Authority_Responsible: Refugee Division, reviewed by judicial authority

Application_Facts: Alleged bias due to relationships between board members and candidates; procedural violations in election processes
Procedural_Issue: Alleged procedural violations in election processes
Principles of natural justice and procedural fairness
Evidence_Used: No evidence of actual bias or significant procedural flaws
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of evidence supporting bias or procedural impact
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of Appeal Board's decision

Legal_Issue: Whether the immigration officer's decision was reasonable based on excessive demand on health services
Evidence_Assessment: Reliance on Dr. Hindle's medical narrative over Dr. Belli's reports; failure to consider financial resources and willingness to pay
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate unreasonableness of decision
Credibility_Factor: Contradictory medical opinions: Dr. Hindle vs. Dr. Belli
Legal_Rule: A person is inadmissible if their health condition may cause excessive demand on health or social services
Grounds_for_Claim: Incomplete medical evidence and failure to consider relevant factors such as financial capacity
Outcome_on_Merits: Applicant succeeded on grounds of unreasonableness
Key_Evidence_Considered: Dr. Belli's report indicating stable condition and low likelihood of surgery within five years; Dr. Hindle's contradictory narrative
Legal_Framework: IRPA, reasonableness standard in administrative decision-making
Outcome: Decision set aside; case remanded for reconsideration by another immigration officer
Legal_Provision: IRPA - Excessive demand on health/social services (s. 38(1)(c))

Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Statutory interpretation of IRPA sections 162(1) and 68(4)
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Explicit statutory language of s. 68(4) limits IAD’s role to factual determinations, overriding general jurisdiction under s. 162(1)

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to inform authorities of address change under Immigration Act
Legal_Issue: Does the statutory stay under s. 49(1)(c)(i) of the Immigration Act apply when an application for leave and judicial review is made out of time?
Outcome: Removal order stayed by operation of law under s. 49(1)(c)(i); no further court order required
Basis_of_Claim: Applicant missed deadline for judicial review due to failure to update address; sought extension and statutory stay
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Statutory stay applies even if application is late, per Mackay decision
Application_Error: Missed filing deadline for judicial review
Legal_Standard: Operation of statutory stay under s. 49(1)(c)(i)
Application_Factor: Intent to file judicial review despite late filing
Decision_Outcome: Stay effective by operation of law
Authority: Immigration Act, s. 49(1)(c)(i); Mackay's decision as precedent

Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act provisions on authorized stay
Application_Facts: Ziyadah overstayed visa, applied for refugee status, was rejected, filed judicial review late
Procedural_Issue: Late filing of judicial review application
Decision_Outcome: Removal order stayed by operation of law; motion for stay dismissed as unnecessary
Outcome: Statutory stay granted under s. 49(1)(c)(i) despite late filing
Relief_Sought: Stay of removal pending judicial review
Remedy_Sought: Extension of time to file judicial review
Legal_Standard_Applied: Interpretation of s. 49(1)(c)(i) and applicability to late applications
Decision_Rationale: Consistency and rationality in law; adoption of Mackay’s reasoning

Dispute_Type: Judicial review of citizenship application decision
Legal_Issue: Whether the Citizenship Judge erred in applying the physical presence test for residency requirements under paragraph 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act
Outcome: Minister's judicial review application granted; Citizenship Judge's decision overturned
Evidence_Type: Record of physical presence days in Canada
Legal_Provision: Paragraph 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act requiring 1,095 days of physical presence in Canada within four years prior to application
Basis_of_Claim: Respondent was two days short of the required 1,095-day physical presence period
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Physical presence requirement cannot be waived by Citizenship Judge; no discretion to blend tests or deem shortfall insignificant
Application_Error: Improper blending of residency tests and treating a two-day shortfall as insignificant
Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied to Citizenship Judge's interpretation of residency requirements
Legal_Standard: Statutory compliance with 1,095-day physical presence requirement under s. 5(1)(c)
Application_Factor: Number of days physically present in Canada during the four-year period preceding application
Decision_Outcome: Decision set aside; Respondent may reapply if eligible
Authority: Federal Court (implied from judicial review context)

Legal_Issue: Failure to provide adequate reasons for granting leave to appeal

Evidence_Assessment: Appeal lacked new evidence or identified legal errors

Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness or correctness, as applicable to administrative decisions
Grounds_for_Claim: Procedural unfairness, lack of reasons, failure to comply with procedural requirements
Outcome_on_Merits: Not reached; decision set aside for reconsideration
Legal_Framework: Canada Pension Plan, Rule 4 of appeal procedures
Defendant_Response: Attorney General of Canada filed judicial review application
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review, setting aside of decision
Outcome: Judicial review allowed; decision set aside; matter remitted for reconsideration

Legal_Issue: Whether the Respondent's trademark BOJANGLES CAFÉ was distinctive
Procedural_Stage: Appeal from Trademarks Opposition Board decision
Evidence_Assessment: Applicants' evidence of mark's presence in Canada through advertising and customer exposure
Decision_Outcome: Board's decision upheld; appeal dismissed with costs
Burden_of_Proof: Applicants failed to prove substantial reputation in Canada
Legal_Rule: A trademark is distinctive if it distinguishes wares or services; opposing mark must be known 'to some extent at least'
Grounds_for_Claim: Opposition to registration based on prior use and reputation of Applicants' mark
Outcome_on_Merits: Respondent's mark found distinctive; opposition unsuccessful
Defendant_Response: BOJANGLES CAFÉ is distinctive and registrable
Evidence_Type: Commercial use, advertising materials, consumer recognition
